query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Guardando nel suo Figlio con l’Amore 2 che l’uno e l’altro etternalmente spira, 3 lo primo e ineffabile Valore
4 quanto per mente e per loco si gira 5 con tant’ ordine fé, ch’esser non puote 6 sanza gustar di lui chi ciò rimira.
query.result:
1 Looking in His Son with the Love 2 that the one and the other eternally breathes out, 3 the first and ineffable Value
4 however much it turns by mind and by place 5 with so much order He made, that to be cannot 6 without tasting of Him who this beholds.

7 Lift therefore, reader, to the high wheels 8 with me the sight, straight to that part 9 where the one movement and the other collide;
10 and there begins to wander in the art 11 of that master who within Himself loves it, 12 so much that never from it does the eye depart.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Vedi come da indi si dirama 14 l’oblico cerchio che i pianeti porta, 15 per sodisfare al mondo che li chiama.
query.result: 13 See how from there it branches out 14 the oblique circle that carries the planets, 15 to satisfy the world that calls them.

16 If their road were not twisted, 17 much virtue in heaven would be in vain, 18 and almost every power down here dead;
19 and if from the straight more or less distant 20 were the starting, much would be less 21 and down and up of the world’s order.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Or ti riman, lettor, sovra ’l tuo banco, 23 dietro pensando a ciò che si preliba, 24 s’esser vuoi lieto assai prima che stanco.
query.result: 22 Now remain, reader, over your bench, 23 behind thinking to that which is delighted in, 24 if you wish to be very happy before being tired.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Messo t’ho innanzi: omai per te ti ciba; 26 ché a sé torce tutta la mia cura 27 quella materia ond’ io son fatto scriba.

Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Lo ministro maggior de la natura, 29 che del valor del ciel lo mondo imprenta 30 e col suo lume il tempo ne misura,
31 con quella parte che sù si rammenta 32 congiunto, si girava per le spire 33 in che più tosto ognora s’appresenta;
34 e io era con lui; ma del salire 35 non m’accors’ io, se non com’ uom s’accorge, 36 anzi ’l primo pensier, del suo venire.

Please translate each line literally into English.
37 È Bëatrice quella che sì scorge 38 di bene in meglio, sì subitamente 39 che l’atto suo per tempo non si sporge.
query.result: 37 It is Beatrice who so perceives 38 of good to better, so suddenly 39 that her act does not protrude through time.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Quant’ esser convenia da sé lucente 41 quel ch’era dentro al sol dov’ io entra’mi, 42 non per color, ma per lume parvente!
43 Perch’ io lo ’ngegno e l’arte e l’uso chiami, 44 sì nol direi che mai s’imaginasse; 45 ma creder puossi e di veder si brami.
query.result:
40 How necessary it was from itself shining 41 that which was within the sun where I entered, 42 not through color, but through appearing light!
43 Because I call the intellect and the art and the use, 44 so I would not say that ever it imagined; 45 but it can be believed and of seeing is desired.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E se le fantasie nostre son basse 47 a tanta altezza, non è maraviglia; 48 ché sopra ’l sol non fu occhio ch’andasse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Tal era quivi la quarta famiglia 50 de l’alto Padre, che sempre la sazia, 51 mostrando come spira e come figlia.
query.result: 49 Such was there the fourth family 50 of the high Father, who always satisfies it, 51 showing how it breathes and how it is born.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 E Bëatrice cominciò: «Ringrazia, 53 ringrazia il Sol de li angeli, ch’a questo 54 sensibil t’ha levato per sua grazia».
query.result: 52 And Beatrice began: “Thank, 53 thank the Sun of the angels, who to this 54 has raised you through his grace.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Cor di mortal non fu mai sì digesto 56 a divozione e a rendersi a Dio 57 con tutto ’l suo gradir cotanto presto,
58 come a quelle parole mi fec’ io; 59 e sì tutto ’l mio amore in lui si mise, 60 che Bëatrice eclissò ne l’oblio.
query.result:
55 Heart of mortal never was so ready 56 for devotion and to give himself to God 57 with all his pleasure so quickly,
58 as I made myself to those words; 59 and so all my love in him was placed, 60 that Beatrice eclipsed into oblivion.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Non le dispiacque; ma sì se ne rise, 62 che lo splendor de li occhi suoi ridenti 63 mia mente unita in più cose divise.
query.result: 61 It did not displease her; but she laughed at it so, 62 that the splendor of her laughing eyes 63 my mind united in more things divided.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Io vidi più folgór vivi e vincenti 65 far di noi centro e di sé far corona, 66 più dolci in voce che in vista lucenti:
67 così cinger la figlia di Latona 68 vedem talvolta, quando l’aere è pregno, 69 sì che ritenga il fil che fa la zona.
query.result:
64 I saw more living and victorious flashes 65 make of us center and of themselves make crown, 66 more sweet in voice than shining in sight:
67 thus to encircle the daughter of Latona 68 we sometimes see, when the air is pregnant, 69 so that it holds the thread that makes the zone.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Poi, sì cantando, quelli ardenti soli 77 si fuor girati intorno a noi tre volte, 78 come stelle vicine a’ fermi poli,
79 donne mi parver, non da ballo sciolte, 80 ma che s’arrestin tacite, ascoltando 81 fin che le nove note hanno ricolte.
query.result:
76 Then, thus singing, those burning suns 77 were turned outside around us three times, 78 as stars close to the fixed poles,
79 women they seemed to me, not loosened for dancing, 80 but that they stop silent, listening 81 until the nine notes have been collected.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E dentro a l’un senti’ cominciar: «Quando 83 lo raggio de la grazia, onde s’accende 84 verace amore e che poi cresce amando,
85 multiplicato in te tanto resplende, 86 che ti conduce su per quella scala 87 u’ sanza risalir nessun discende;
88 qual ti negasse il vin de la sua fiala 89 per la tua sete, in libertà non fora 90 se non com’ acqua ch’al mar non si cala.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Tu vuo’ saper di quai piante s’infiora 92 questa ghirlanda che ’ntorno vagheggia 93 la bella donna ch’al ciel t’avvalora.
query.result: 91 You want to know of what plants flowers 92 this garland that around wanders 93 the beautiful woman who to heaven strengthens you.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Io fui de li agni de la santa greggia 95 che Domenico mena per cammino 96 u’ ben s’impingua se non si vaneggia.
query.result: 94 I was of the lambs of the holy flock 95 that Dominic leads along the path 96 where one grows fat well if one does not wander.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Questi che m’è a destra più vicino, 98 frate e maestro fummi, ed esso Alberto 99 è di Cologna, e io Thomas d’Aquino.
query.result: 97 This one who is closer to me on the right, 98 brother and teacher he appeared to me, and he is Alberto 99 of Cologne, and I Thomas of Aquino.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 Se sì di tutti li altri esser vuo’ certo, 101 di retro al mio parlar ten vien col viso 102 girando su per lo beato serto.
query.result: 100 If you wish to be certain of all the others, 101 behind my speaking he comes with the face 102 turning up toward the blessed crown.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Quell’ altro fiammeggiare esce del riso 104 di Grazïan, che l’uno e l’altro foro 105 aiutò sì che piace in paradiso.
query.result: 103 That other gleaming comes from the wit 104 of Grazian, who both holes 105 helped so that it pleases in paradise.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 L’altro ch’appresso addorna il nostro coro, 107 quel Pietro fu che con la poverella 108 offerse a Santa Chiesa suo tesoro.
query.result: 106 The other one who adorns our choir nearby, 107 that Peter was who with the poor woman 108 offered to Holy Church his treasure.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 La quinta luce, ch’è tra noi più bella, 110 spira di tale amor, che tutto ’l mondo 111 là giù ne gola di saper novella:
112 entro v’è l’alta mente u’ sì profondo 113 saver fu messo, che, se ’l vero è vero, 114 a veder tanto non surse il secondo.
query.result:
109 The fifth light, which is most beautiful among us, 110 breathes of such love, that all the world 111 down there in the throat desires new knowledge:
112 within there is the high mind so deep 113 knowledge was placed, that, if the truth is true, 114 to see so much no second arose.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 Appresso vedi il lume di quel cero 116 che giù in carne più a dentro vide 117 l’angelica natura e ’l ministero.
query.result: 115 Nearby you see the light of that candle 116 who down in the flesh more within saw 117 the angelic nature and the ministry.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Ne l’altra piccioletta luce ride 119 quello avvocato de’ tempi cristiani 120 del cui latino Augustin si provide.
query.result: 118 In the other small light laughs 119 that advocate of the Christian times 120 from whose Latin Augustine is supplied.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Or se tu l’occhio de la mente trani 122 di luce in luce dietro a le mie lode, 123 già de l’ottava con sete rimani.
query.result: 121 Now if you the eye of the mind pass 122 from light to light behind my praises, 123 already of the eighth you will remain with thirst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Per vedere ogne ben dentro vi gode 125 l’anima santa che ’l mondo fallace 126 fa manifesto a chi di lei ben ode.
query.result: 124 To see every good within it enjoys 125 the holy soul that the deceitful world 126 makes manifest to whoever hears it well.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Lo corpo ond’ ella fu cacciata giace 128 giuso in Cieldauro; ed essa da martiro 129 e da essilio venne a questa pace.
query.result: 127 The body from which she was cast down lies 128 down in Cieldauro; and she from martyrdom 129 and from exile came to this peace.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Vedi oltre fiammeggiar l’ardente spiro 131 d’Isidoro, di Beda e di Riccardo, 132 che a considerar fu più che viro.
query.result: 130 See beyond flaming the ardent spirit 131 of Isidore, of Bede and of Richard, 132 who was more than a man in considering.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Questi onde a me ritorna il tuo riguardo, 134 è ’l lume d’uno spirto che ’n pensieri 135 gravi a morir li parve venir tardo:
136 essa è la luce etterna di Sigieri, 137 che, leggendo nel Vico de li Strami, 138 silogizzò invidïosi veri».
query.result:
133 These, whence to me returns your regard, 134 is the light of a spirit who in thoughts 135 heavy to die seemed to come late:
136 This is the eternal light of Sigerius, 137 who, reading in the Vico de li Strami, 138 syllogized envious truths.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Indi, come orologio che ne chiami 140 ne l’ora che la sposa di Dio surge 141 a mattinar lo sposo perché l’ami,
142 che l’una parte e l’altra tira e urge, 143 tin tin sonando con sì dolce nota, 144 che ’l ben disposto spirto d’amor turge;
145 così vid’ ïo la gloriosa rota 146 muoversi e render voce a voce in tempra 147 e in dolcezza ch’esser non pò nota
148 se non colà dove gioir s’insempra.
query.result:
139 Then, as a clock that calls in 140 in the hour that the bride of God rises 141 to greet the bridegroom because she loves him,
142 that one part and the other pulls and urges, 143 tin tin sounding with so sweet a note, 144 that the well-disposed spirit of love swells;
145 thus I saw the glorious wheel 146 move and render voice to voice in temper 147 and in sweetness which cannot be noted
148 if not there where joy is always learned.
